elements.content: Postsynthetic modification (PSM) of amino-functionalized metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) to those bearing pendant β-amidoketone arms using diketene is herein reported. Three unique MOF families demonstrate the scope of this transformation, which both is atom-economical and yields high conversions. In each case, the crystallinity was retained, and instances of exceptional solid-state ordering were observed in the PSM products, which has allowed detailed crystallographic characterization in multiple instances.
elements.clean_text: Postsynthetic modification (PSM) of amino-functionalized metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) to those bearing pendant β-amidoketone arms using diketene is herein reported. Three unique MOF families demonstrate the scope of this transformation, which both is atom-economical and yields high conversions. In each case, the crystallinity was retained, and instances of exceptional solid-state ordering were observed in the PSM products, which has allowed detailed crystallographic characterization in multiple instances.

elements.content: Postsynthetic modification (PSM) of amino-functionalized metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) to pendant β-amidoketone arms using diketene has been demonstrated with three unique MOF families. The PSM reaction both is atom-economical and yields high conversion percentages. In each case, the crystallinity was retained, and instances of exceptional solid-state ordering were observed in the PSM products.
elements.clean_text: Postsynthetic modification (PSM) of amino-functionalized metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) to pendant β-amidoketone arms using diketene has been demonstrated with three unique MOF families. The PSM reaction both is atom-economical and yields high conversion percentages. In each case, the crystallinity was retained, and instances of exceptional solid-state ordering were observed in the PSM products.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are hybrid inorganic–organic materials that show exceptional promise across a range of applications, such as catalysis, gas adsorption, separation and storage, vessels for crystallographic viewing of chemical reactions, and both magnetic and optical devices. Many of the physical properties behind these applications rely on the predetermined functional groups that are present within the pores of the MOF architectures. While MOF pores can be furnished with simple functional groups by prefunctionalizing the organic linker, the scope of such chemistry has been limited by the harsh synthetic protocols inherent to many MOF syntheses. This limitation can be overcome by adopting a postsynthetic modification (PSM) strategy, in which the chemical and physical properties of MOF materials are modified in a heterogeneous fashion. This strategy has been essential for the placement of reactive functional groups within MOF pores that could not otherwise be synthetically achieved using a prefunctionalization approach.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are hybrid inorganic-organic materials that show exceptional promise across a range of applications, such as catalysis, gas adsorption, separation and storage, vessels for crystallographic viewing of chemical reactions, and both magnetic and optical devices. Many of the physical properties behind these applications rely on the predetermined functional groups that are present within the pores of the MOF architectures. While MOF pores can be furnished with simple functional groups by prefunctionalizing the organic linker, the scope of such chemistry has been limited by the harsh synthetic protocols inherent to many MOF syntheses. This limitation can be overcome by adopting a postsynthetic modification (PSM) strategy, in which the chemical and physical properties of MOF materials are modified in a heterogeneous fashion. This strategy has been essential for the placement of reactive functional groups within MOF pores that could not otherwise be synthetically achieved using a prefunctionalization approach.

elements.content: One of the main means of facilitating PSM reactions is covalent modification, wherein the organic linkers are reacted after MOF formation. Notable examples include the oxidation of sulfur-tagged MOFs with dimethyldioxirane, amine-induced ring-opening reactions of sultones or aziridines, conversion of amines to reactive thio- and isocyanates, and “click” chemistry performed on azides derived from amine groups. In each instance, more complex functionalities were produced after the identification of a suitable organic reaction or reagent, ultimately providing new materials and properties. Herein we report the discovery of a new PSM reaction involving the reaction of diketene with MOFs prefunctionalized with amine groups (). The reaction yields β-amidoketones in a facile, high-yielding and atom-economical fashion. This reaction is of further significance owing to the noncarcinogenic nature of diketene, the known metal-chelating ability of the resulting β-amidoketone group, and the prevalence of solid-state ordering observed in many of the resulting PSM products, allowing direct crystallographic characterization for multiple modified MOFs. Aminated MOFs have previously been reacted with maleic anhydride and glyoxal, but in those cases, the resulting functionalities were less ordered.
elements.clean_text: One of the main means of facilitating PSM reactions is covalent modification, wherein the organic linkers are reacted after MOF formation. Notable examples include the oxidation of sulfur-tagged MOFs with dimethyldioxirane, amine-induced ring-opening reactions of sultones or aziridines, conversion of amines to reactive thio- and isocyanates, and "click" chemistry performed on azides derived from amine groups. In each instance, more complex functionalities were produced after the identification of a suitable organic reaction or reagent, ultimately providing new materials and properties. Herein we report the discovery of a new PSM reaction involving the reaction of diketene with MOFs prefunctionalized with amine groups (). The reaction yields β-amidoketones in a facile, high-yielding and atom-economical fashion. This reaction is of further significance owing to the noncarcinogenic nature of diketene, the known metal-chelating ability of the resulting β-amidoketone group, and the prevalence of solid-state ordering observed in many of the resulting PSM products, allowing direct crystallographic characterization for multiple modified MOFs. Aminated MOFs have previously been reacted with maleic anhydride and glyoxal, but in those cases, the resulting functionalities were less ordered.

elements.content: PSM reaction of postactivated amino-functionalized MOFs (MOF-NH2) with diketene to yield β-amidoketones (MOF-NHak).
elements.clean_text: 1  PSM reaction of postactivated amino-functionalized MOFs (MOF-NH2) with diketene to yield β-amidoketones (MOF-NHak).

elements.content: To best demonstrate the applicability of this new β-amidoketone-forming PSM reaction, three well-known MOFs and a mixed-ligand system (section S1, Supporting Information) were targeted: DMOF-1-NH2, [Zn2(bdc-NH2)2(dabco)] (bdc-NH2 = 2-amino-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, dabco = 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]­octane) [Zn2(bdc)­(bdc-NH2)­(dabco)] (bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate); IRMOF-3, [Zn4O­(bdc-NH2)3]; Fujita’s crystalline sponge (FCS) FCS-NH2, [Zn3I6(tpt)2]·atp-NH2 [tpt = 2,4,6-tris­(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine and atp-NH2 = aminotriphenylene]. The PSM conversions ranged from 82% to quantitative, as judged by 1H NMR spectroscopy.
elements.clean_text: To best demonstrate the applicability of this new β-amidoketone-forming PSM reaction, three well-known MOFs and a mixed-ligand system (section S1, Supporting Information) were targeted: DMOF-1-NH2, [Zn2(bdc-NH2)2(dabco)] (bdc-NH2 = 2-amino-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, dabco = 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane) [Zn2(bdc)(bdc-NH2)(dabco)] (bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate); IRMOF-3, [Zn4O(bdc-NH2)3]; Fujita's crystalline sponge (FCS) FCS-NH2, [Zn3I6(tpt)2]⋅atp-NH2 [tpt = 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine and atp-NH2 = aminotriphenylene]. The PSM conversions ranged from 82% to quantitative, as judged by 1H NMR spectroscopy.

elements.content: DMOF-1-NHak (1). 1H NMR spectroscopy was used to gauge the percentage conversion of bdc-NH2 to the PSM ligand 3-[(1,3-dioxobutyl)­amino]­benzenedicarboxylate (bdc-NHak) on digested samples of [Zn2(bdc-NH2)0.32(bdc-NHak)1.68(dabco)]·DMF (DMOF-1-NHak, 1). Upon assignment of the conversion percentage, aromatic signals were generally used to aid comparisons with the parent ligands. 1H NMR analysis of a bulk crystalline sample of 1 identified both keto/enol tautomerism of the terminal ketone group and the overall PSM conversion percentage. These data are presented in along with those of 2 and 3. Full 1H NMR assignments for the conversion of each MOF species may be found in the Supporting Information (sections S2 and S3).
elements.clean_text: DMOF-1-NHak (1). 1H NMR spectroscopy was used to gauge the percentage conversion of bdc-NH2 to the PSM ligand 3-[(1,3-dioxobutyl)amino]benzenedicarboxylate (bdc-NHak) on digested samples of [Zn2(bdc-NH2)0.32(bdc-NHak)1.68(dabco)]⋅DMF (DMOF-1-NHak, 1). Upon assignment of the conversion percentage, aromatic signals were generally used to aid comparisons with the parent ligands. 1H NMR analysis of a bulk crystalline sample of 1 identified both keto/enol tautomerism of the terminal ketone group and the overall PSM conversion percentage. These data are presented in  along with those of 2 and 3. Full 1H NMR assignments for the conversion of each MOF species may be found in the Supporting Information (sections S2 and S3).

elements.content:
Summary of the <sup>1</sup>H NMR Results for <bold>1</bold>–<bold>3</bold> MOF digestion media NHak (k:e) ratio convn (%) 1 30:1 DMSO-d 6/DCl (35 wt % in D2O) 10:1 84 2 30:1 DMSO-d 6/DCl (35 wt % in D2O) 10:1 82 3 DMF-d 7 3.3:1 100

keto/enol ratio of digested bdc-NHak assigned from integrals of the ortho-ring singlet resonance from each tautomer.

The PSM reaction resulted in no outward changes to the crystalline appearance of 1. The framework crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/m, with the asymmetric unit containing half of a zinc atom, half of a bdc ligand (comprised of 16:84 bdc-NH2/bdc-NHak), a quarter of a dabco ligand, and some guest solvent. The structure contains a zinc-paddlewheel secondary building unit capped by dabco ligands (), forming the pillared MOF motif that is typical of this type of material.
elements.clean_text: The PSM reaction resulted in no outward changes to the crystalline appearance of 1. The framework crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/m, with the asymmetric unit containing half of a zinc atom, half of a bdc ligand (comprised of 16:84 bdc-NH2/bdc-NHak), a quarter of a dabco ligand, and some guest solvent. The structure contains a zinc-paddlewheel secondary building unit capped by dabco ligands (), forming the pillared MOF motif that is typical of this type of material.

elements.content: (a) View down the crystallographic c axis showing the PSM groups disordered over two sites within the channels of DMOF-1-NHak. (b) Paddlewheel coordination environment of Zn2+ in DMOF-1-NHak.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) View down the crystallographic c axis showing the PSM groups disordered over two sites within the channels of DMOF-1-NHak. (b) Paddlewheel coordination environment of Zn2+ in DMOF-1-NHak.

elements.content: Crystallographic analysis of DMOF-1-NHak revealed that the ordering of the PSM product within the pores was sufficient to visualize all but the methyl terminus of the −NHak tag. The terminal methyl group on this PSM arm could not be reliably located owing to smearing of the electron density with increasing distance from the ligand core. This was further evidenced by the increasing atomic displacement parameter (ADP) size proceeding along the −NHak chain. This observation is exceptional for functionalized MOFs given that the electron density pertaining to the functional groups present within the MOF pores typically proves far too diffuse to allow crystallographic modeling. In this model, the ligand moiety straddles a crystallographic inversion center, which necessarily means that the −NH2 and −NHak tags are disordered between two positions on the phenyl ring. Beyond the anchoring nitrogen atom, the PSM chain possesses atom occupancies of 42%, reflecting the 84% conversion of the amino groups in the PSM reaction. The dabco carbon atoms similarly exhibit disorder, which is unsurprising considering that this entity does not have mirror symmetry along the N···N vector. A full discussion of the disorder observed for 1, as well as that of a 1:1 bdc/bdc-NH2 mixed-ligand variant can be found in the Supporting Information (sections S4 and S5).
elements.clean_text: Crystallographic analysis of DMOF-1-NHak revealed that the ordering of the PSM product within the pores was sufficient to visualize all but the methyl terminus of the -NHak tag. The terminal methyl group on this PSM arm could not be reliably located owing to smearing of the electron density with increasing distance from the ligand core. This was further evidenced by the increasing atomic displacement parameter (ADP) size proceeding along the -NHak chain. This observation is exceptional for functionalized MOFs given that the electron density pertaining to the functional groups present within the MOF pores typically proves far too diffuse to allow crystallographic modeling. In this model, the ligand moiety straddles a crystallographic inversion center, which necessarily means that the -NH2 and -NHak tags are disordered between two positions on the phenyl ring. Beyond the anchoring nitrogen atom, the PSM chain possesses atom occupancies of 42%, reflecting the 84% conversion of the amino groups in the PSM reaction. The dabco carbon atoms similarly exhibit disorder, which is unsurprising considering that this entity does not have mirror symmetry along the N⋅⋅⋅N vector. A full discussion of the disorder observed for 1, as well as that of a 1:1 bdc/bdc-NH2 mixed-ligand variant can be found in the Supporting Information (sections S4 and S5).

elements.content: A recent study of mixed-ligand bdc/bdc-NH2 variants of DMOF-1 identified a distorted square-pore geometry in which the ligands were offset when viewed down the crystallographic c axis, yet here it is the [Zn2(CO2)4] secondary building unit that distorts (b), which allows the ligands to align in an eclipsed fashion. The zinc ions within the paddlewheel motif are misaligned by ca. 15° relative to the N···N vector of the dabco ligands, which likely provides a more amenable pore cavity to enclose the larger functional group within the channels. Ultimately, this distorts the regular square-grid topology of the framework, as described by the aforementioned study.
elements.clean_text: A recent study of mixed-ligand bdc/bdc-NH2 variants of DMOF-1 identified a distorted square-pore geometry in which the ligands were offset when viewed down the crystallographic c axis, yet here it is the [Zn2(CO2)4] secondary building unit that distorts (b), which allows the ligands to align in an eclipsed fashion. The zinc ions within the paddlewheel motif are misaligned by ca. 15° relative to the N⋅⋅⋅N vector of the dabco ligands, which likely provides a more amenable pore cavity to enclose the larger functional group within the channels. Ultimately, this distorts the regular square-grid topology of the framework, as described by the aforementioned study.

elements.content: IRMOF-3-NHak (2). Spectroscopic analyses provided evidence for the PSM reaction of IRMOF-3 with diketene. Qualitative evidence of the reaction to 2 could be observed microscopically because single crystals of IRMOF-3 became opaque and yellow in color postreaction. Despite excellent diffraction of the crystals when irradiated with X-rays, a lack of ordering of the PSM group within the MOF pores prevented reliable modeling of more than the initial nitrogen atom. Consequently, the obtained crystal data offer no insight beyond the previously reported IRMOF-3 and have not been included here. Two new prominent bands were observed in the IR spectrum at 1755 and 1662 cm–1, which correspond to the newly formed keto and amido groups. As with the DMOF species 1, loss of the primary amine bands at 3474 and 3351 cm–1 from the parent MOF was also evident postreaction.
elements.clean_text: IRMOF-3-NHak (2). Spectroscopic analyses provided evidence for the PSM reaction of IRMOF-3 with diketene. Qualitative evidence of the reaction to 2 could be observed microscopically because single crystals of IRMOF-3 became opaque and yellow in color postreaction. Despite excellent diffraction of the crystals when irradiated with X-rays, a lack of ordering of the PSM group within the MOF pores prevented reliable modeling of more than the initial nitrogen atom. Consequently, the obtained crystal data offer no insight beyond the previously reported IRMOF-3 and have not been included here. Two new prominent bands were observed in the IR spectrum at 1755 and 1662 cm-1, which correspond to the newly formed keto and amido groups. As with the DMOF species 1, loss of the primary amine bands at 3474 and 3351 cm-1 from the parent MOF was also evident postreaction.

elements.content: The 1H NMR spectrum of bdc-NHak obtained from 2 was similar to that of the digested DMOF-1 species 1 (Figure S1). In each instance, the aromatic signals are shifted downfield relative to the reference acid, H2bdc-NH2, upon undergoing the PSM reaction. This effect is most pronounced for the hydrogen atom in the ortho position relative to the amine group, which shifts from 7.62 ppm to ca. 9 ppm. The remaining aromatic hydrogen atoms are also deshielded in each instance, albeit to a lesser degree. Evidence for the carboxylic acid and amido hydrogen atoms was typically absent from the 1H NMR spectrum, owing to facile exchange with deuterium chloride of the digestion media; however, evidence for the methylene and terminal methyl groups could typically be observed in the region from 2 to 3 ppm.
elements.clean_text: The 1H NMR spectrum of bdc-NHak obtained from 2 was similar to that of the digested DMOF-1 species 1 (Figure S1). In each instance, the aromatic signals are shifted downfield relative to the reference acid, H2bdc-NH2, upon undergoing the PSM reaction. This effect is most pronounced for the hydrogen atom in the ortho position relative to the amine group, which shifts from 7.62 ppm to ca. 9 ppm. The remaining aromatic hydrogen atoms are also deshielded in each instance, albeit to a lesser degree. Evidence for the carboxylic acid and amido hydrogen atoms was typically absent from the 1H NMR spectrum, owing to facile exchange with deuterium chloride of the digestion media; however, evidence for the methylene and terminal methyl groups could typically be observed in the region from 2 to 3 ppm.

elements.content: FCS-NHak (3). While the triphenylene group complicated the aromatic region of the 1H NMR spectrum, a considerable quantity of information could still be garnered. The use of DMF-d 7 allowed visualization of both the keto and enol amido N–H resonances at 10.7 and 10.5 ppm, respectively, giving direct evidence for PSM group formation. The enolic OH group was also observed at 14.1 ppm. By contrast, the methylene and terminal methyl groups of the keto PSM arm were observed at 3.95 and 2.50 ppm, respectively. There was evidence of an unreacted primary amine cartridge, and of the species found within the pores, 1 equiv of unreacted diketene was assigned based on the characteristic terminal methylene resonances at 5.01 and 4.74 ppm and a multiplet that integrated for two hydrogen atoms at 4.39 ppm was attributed to the methylene group of the oxetane ring.
elements.clean_text: FCS-NHak (3). While the triphenylene group complicated the aromatic region of the 1H NMR spectrum, a considerable quantity of information could still be garnered. The use of DMF-d 7 allowed visualization of both the keto and enol amido N-H resonances at 10.7 and 10.5 ppm, respectively, giving direct evidence for PSM group formation. The enolic OH group was also observed at 14.1 ppm. By contrast, the methylene and terminal methyl groups of the keto PSM arm were observed at 3.95 and 2.50 ppm, respectively. There was evidence of an unreacted primary amine cartridge, and of the species found within the pores, 1 equiv of unreacted diketene was assigned based on the characteristic terminal methylene resonances at 5.01 and 4.74 ppm and a multiplet that integrated for two hydrogen atoms at 4.39 ppm was attributed to the methylene group of the oxetane ring.

elements.content: This system provided a second visual means of outwardly observing the PSM reaction. Electronic changes in the aminotriphenylene “cartridge” upon PSM reaction within FCS-NH2 resulted in a color change in the crystals from red to yellow (Figure S9). This is consistent with other reports of chemical reactions undertaken in Fujita’s crystalline flasks. After upward of 20 samples were screened, suitable single crystals of FCS-NHak were found and analyzed. The asymmetric unit was found to contain three zinc centers, six iodides, two tridentate neutral triazine-based ligands, a postsynthetically modified triphenylene molecule, and some diffuse guest solvent ().
elements.clean_text: This system provided a second visual means of outwardly observing the PSM reaction. Electronic changes in the aminotriphenylene "cartridge" upon PSM reaction within FCS-NH2 resulted in a color change in the crystals from red to yellow (Figure S9). This is consistent with other reports of chemical reactions undertaken in Fujita's crystalline flasks. After upward of 20 samples were screened, suitable single crystals of FCS-NHak were found and analyzed. The asymmetric unit was found to contain three zinc centers, six iodides, two tridentate neutral triazine-based ligands, a postsynthetically modified triphenylene molecule, and some diffuse guest solvent ().

elements.content: Modeled asymmetric unit of FCS-NHak. The PSM chain could only be reliably modeled to the methylene group (shown here as NHac). Ellipsoids are shown with 50% probability. Diffuse solvent molecules are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 3  Modeled asymmetric unit of FCS-NHak. The PSM chain could only be reliably modeled to the methylene group (shown here as NHac). Ellipsoids are shown with 50% probability. Diffuse solvent molecules are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Resolving MOF framework 3, which comprises three repeating ZnI2 nodes linked by two tpt linkers, from the X-ray diffraction data was relatively straightforward. The derivatized triphenylene guest is sandwiched between two tpt ligands, each from distinct, interpenetrated layers of the framework (, inset). Two types of large pores are present, of which only one contains the PSM tag of atp-NHak, consistent with previous reports. Disorder of the triphenylene group over two proximate positions was observed (full details are given in the Supporting Information). Consequently, it was not possible to reliably locate the terminal CH3CO portion of the side chain, and thus it was omitted from the refinement along with the hydrogen atoms attached to methylene bridge carbon atom (i.e., the carbon terminus of NHac shown in ). The site occupancy of these atoms was treated as unity, based on 1H NMR evidence for 100% PSM conversion.
elements.clean_text: Resolving MOF framework 3, which comprises three repeating ZnI2 nodes linked by two tpt linkers, from the X-ray diffraction data was relatively straightforward. The derivatized triphenylene guest is sandwiched between two tpt ligands, each from distinct, interpenetrated layers of the framework (, inset). Two types of large pores are present, of which only one contains the PSM tag of atp-NHak, consistent with previous reports. Disorder of the triphenylene group over two proximate positions was observed (full details are given in the Supporting Information). Consequently, it was not possible to reliably locate the terminal CH3CO portion of the side chain, and thus it was omitted from the refinement along with the hydrogen atoms attached to methylene bridge carbon atom (i.e., the carbon terminus of NHac shown in ). The site occupancy of these atoms was treated as unity, based on 1H NMR evidence for 100% PSM conversion.

elements.content: This postsynthetic reaction is exceptional in that the single crystallinity of the products was universally retained using these protocols, and the resulting modified group was directly crystallographically observable in three of the four cases studied. These features are extremely valuable because powder X-ray diffraction patterns of MOF frameworks are typically unchanged upon PSM and hence only serve to gauge the crystallinity of the products. A crystallographic window of the PSM region broadens the application of these materials to paramagnetic species that would interfere with 1H NMR analyses and time-resolved crystallographic processes.
elements.clean_text: This postsynthetic reaction is exceptional in that the single crystallinity of the products was universally retained using these protocols, and the resulting modified group was directly crystallographically observable in three of the four cases studied. These features are extremely valuable because powder X-ray diffraction patterns of MOF frameworks are typically unchanged upon PSM and hence only serve to gauge the crystallinity of the products. A crystallographic window of the PSM region broadens the application of these materials to paramagnetic species that would interfere with 1H NMR analyses and time-resolved crystallographic processes.

elements.content: In summary, we have identified and evaluated the scope of a new PSM reaction that has exciting implications for MOF chemistry. The transformation imparts consistently high conversions (>80%) and is atom-economical, synthetically easily achieved, and applicable to a range of common MOF families. The resulting β-amidoketone group is a known metal chelating group with acidic character, opening the MOF pore to a host of further transformations. We are currently investigating these reactions on a range of β-amidoketone-functionalized MOFs. This combination of synthetic ease and useful functionality leads to the recommendation of this PSM transformation for widespread implementation within the MOF community.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have identified and evaluated the scope of a new PSM reaction that has exciting implications for MOF chemistry. The transformation imparts consistently high conversions (>80%) and is atom-economical, synthetically easily achieved, and applicable to a range of common MOF families. The resulting β-amidoketone group is a known metal chelating group with acidic character, opening the MOF pore to a host of further transformations. We are currently investigating these reactions on a range of β-amidoketone-functionalized MOFs. This combination of synthetic ease and useful functionality leads to the recommendation of this PSM transformation for widespread implementation within the MOF community.

metadata.title:
Furnishing Amine-Functionalized Metal–Organic Frameworks with
the β‑Amidoketone Group by Postsynthetic Modification
